facts.text: Appellant was the Construction Engineer at Sindhri.
R. Basu was a contractor living in Calcutta carrying on business of Hindustan Engineering and Construction Company.
Prosecution alleged that appellant accepted Rs. 10,000 as illegal gratification from Basu at Kelners Restaurant at Dhanbad Railway Station on July 18, 1951.
Courts below found that appellant accepted the sum of Rs. 10,000 as illegal gratification.
Appellant defended that he took the envelope containing this amount without knowing it contained money, but knowing it contained papers relating to Basu's contracts.
Appellant convicted for offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.
Patna High Court dismissed appellant's appeal against conviction on September 10, 1958.
Offence committed at Dhanbad in Manbhum District; case challaned to Magistrate at Dhanbad.
On application by accused, High Court transferred case to Court of Munsif-Magistrate at Patna.
Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 came into force on July 28, 1952; case forwarded to Special Judge at Patna under s.10.
Appellant visited Calcutta in December 1950, went to Basu's house and asked to pay bribe of Rs. 10,000.
Kanjilal, employee of Basu, met appellant in May 1951, enquired if he would accept Rs.10,000 demanded in December, got affirmative reply.
Basu informed K.N. Mookerjee, SP SPE, in June 1951 about demand; delivered letter dated June 18 mentioning December 1950 demand.
Kanjilal met appellant on July 14, 1951, arranged meeting at Dhanbad station where Basu would pay money.
Kanjilal informed appellant by telephone on July 16 that meeting on 18th, Basu arriving by Toofan Express ~5pm.
Kanjilal went to Sindhri morning of July 18, confirmed arrangement.
Trap party reached Dhanbad by Toofan Express July 18; sat at different tables in Kellners Refreshment Room.

Basu and appellant reached refreshment room, took refreshments, talked about contract, Basu passed envelope containing Rs.10,000 currency notes (numbers noted earlier), said 'there are Rs. 10,000 which I could not pay to you so far'; appellant put in trouser pocket.
Trap party surrounded after signal, recovered envelope with marked notes from appellant.
Appellant explained presence at station; not accepted by courts.
When case taken up by Special Judge Patna on October 23, 1952, accused and PP desired de novo trial; no objection to jurisdiction then.
Objection to jurisdiction taken at arguments before Special Judge, repelled.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions regarding presumption in s.4 of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 are unconstitutional.
Whether Special Judge at Patna had jurisdiction to try the case committed in Manbhum District.
Whether there was proper corroboration of Basu's statement about accused demanding and accepting bribe.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of s.4 of Act unconstitutional as against Art.21 of Constitution.
Case tried by Special Judge Patna who had no jurisdiction; should have been tried by Special Judge Manbhum.
No proper corroboration of Basu's statement about demanding bribe and accepting amount.
s.531 CrPC not applicable due to s.7(1) and s.10 Criminal Law Amendment Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC s.531; Criminal Law Amendment Act s.7(1), s.10

court_reasoning.text: Question of constitutionality of s.4 not substantial question of law under Art.145(3); 'law' in Art.21 means State-made law, s.4 enacted by Parliament is procedure established by law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Refers to A.K. Gopalan; not for 5 judges.

court_reasoning.text: High Court transfer powers under CrPC s.526 apply to Special Judges per s.8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act; no prejudice to appellant who requested Patna transfer; no objection timely raised; s.531 CrPC applies as no failure of justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial at Patna valid; s.531 saves irregularity.

court_reasoning.text: Corroboration from circumstances: demand mentioned timely to police; trap laid expecting appellant; presence not accidental; envelope fat like money, not papers; no query what it contained; purpose of secret meeting not bills.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant knew envelope contained Rs.10,000 bribe demanded.

holdings.text: s.4 of Prevention of Corruption Act constitutional as procedure established by law under Art.21.
Special Judge Patna had jurisdiction; irregularity cured by s.531 CrPC.
Sufficient corroboration of Basu's testimony from circumstances.
Conviction correct; appellant received Rs.10,000 as bribe knowing it.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Law' in Art.21 means State-made law, not natural justice; procedure by State law valid.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption; offence triable by Special Judge.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Special Judges for trial; jurisdiction; CrPC application.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Examination of accused; High Court transfer; cure of jurisdiction error if no failure of justice.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure established by law; minimum judges for constitutional questions.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; conviction under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act upheld; all contentions rejected.

key_quotes.text: 'law' in Art.21 has been used in the sense of State-made law and not as an equivalent of law in the abstract or general sense embodying the principles of natural justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The mere omission of a formal forwarding of this case to the Special Judge at Manbhum and of a formal order of the High Court to transfer it to the Court of the Special Judge at Patna, have not, in our opinion, prejudiced the appellant in any way.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: When it is held that the appellant must have gone to Dhanbad railway station by arrangement, it becomes a moot point, what the purpose of the arrangement was. Surely, it could not have been a mere delivering of certain bills and papers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
